review.title: Automated Reasoning in Deontic Logic
review.abstract: Deontic logic is a very well researched branch of mathematical logic and philosophy. Various kinds of deontic logics are discussed for different application domains like argumentation theory, legal reasoning, and acts in multi-agent systems. In this paper, we show how standard deontic logic can be stepwise transformed into description logic and DL- clauses, such that it can be processed by Hyper, a high performance theorem prover which uses a hypertableau calculus. Two use cases, one from multi-agent research and one from the development of normative system are investigated.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Deontic logic is a very well researched branch of mathematical logic and philosophy. Different types of deontic logic are being discussed for various fields of application such as argumentation theory, legal thinking, and actions in multi-agent systems [11]. Recently, interest in modelling human thinking and testing models with psychological insights has also been growing. Deontic logic is an obvious tool for this purpose, because norms and licenses in human societies can easily be described with it, e.g. the Wason selection task or Byrne's suppression task. In this paper, one focuses on automated thinking in deontic logic (SDL), focusing on the use of deontic logic to model certain effects that occur in human thinking, e.g. the Wason selection task or Byrne's suppression task.

sections.heading: 3.3 Reasoning Tasks
sections.text: With the help of Hyper, we can solve several interesting argumentation problems: 6 - Consistency check of normative systems: In practice, normative systems can be very large. Therefore, it is not easy to determine whether a given normative system is consistent; the tester of the hypertheorem can be used to check the consistency of a normative system N. We first translate N into an ALC knowledge base Φ (N), then we translate Φ (N) into the defined ω (N) of DLclauses; then we can check the consistency of ω (N) by means of hyper.- Assessment of normative systems: In the face of several normative systems, we use Hyper to find out for which normative system a desired result is guaranteed. - Independence check: In the face of a normative system N and a formula F that represents a norm, we can check whether F is independent of N. If F is independent of N, F is not a logical consequence of N.

sections.heading: 4 Applications
sections.text: The literature on deontic logic deals with numerous small but nevertheless interesting examples. They are mostly used to point out typical problems or peculiarities of the logic under consideration (cf. [10]). In Section 4.1 we will deal with one of these examples. In Section 4.2 we formalize a "real" problem from multi-agent research.

In addition, the second number contains the time it takes to convert the ALC knowledge base into DL clauses; the second column indicates the runtimes for the example of multi-agent systems, using the formalization with a TBox; and in the last column, we present the runtimes for the consistency test of the normative system N1 based on the example in contradiction with the duties; the second column indicates the runtimes for the example of multi-agent systems used in the example box with a multi-agent form.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have shown that complex normative systems can be formalized easily using deontic logic, and these formalizations can be effectively verified for consistency and independence from additional formulas. Normative systems described using deontic logic have a one-to-one translation into formulas of descriptive logic. These formulas can be automatically verified by automated theory testers, which in our case is hyper.We are aware that deontic logic has several limitations, which is why future work will focus on the use of newer formalisms.For example, we want to apply deontic logic in the context of systems for answering natural questions, where normative knowledge often leads to inconsistencies in large databases, which motivates us to consider combinations of deontic logic with defect-free logic. 12
